header_summary:
Christopher Allen highlighted the integration of FROST with Bitcoin technology, emphasizing its enhancement of security through Distributed Key Generation and support for Schnorr-based signatures. This effort is showcased through demonstrations and resources aimed at educating developers on FROST's application in Bitcoin transactions, particularly for Taproot adjustments, with significant community support from organizations and individuals ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CACrqygAti5xbuLRyH91dfTE2bwZ5qD+9_k09h-azoLHp1QxKXw@mail.gmail.com/T/#u#m06e634c4563bd6abd3c6c47c82db38c4df4eb924)). 

In another discussion, roconnor-blockstream explores the Simplicity programming language, designed for blockchain development, noting its potential for handling complex computations and cryptographic functions with its minimalistic yet powerful framework. This language facilitates the creation of adaptable and robust programs, paving the way for more secure and efficient smart contracts and blockchain applications, while highlighting the importance of formal verification and optimization strategies ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/delving-simplicity-part-building-data-types/1956)).

Josh argues for the necessity of an independent unit of account, dubbed a "Hayek," underlining the inconsistency in academic acceptance of traditional financial instruments versus digital currencies like Bitcoin. He suggests that Bitcoin's potential to act as a stable unit of account challenges existing financial theories and calls for a reevaluation of asset valuation standards across both traditional and digital assets, promoting a more equitable financial ecosystem ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/a-game-theoretic-approach-to-bitcoin-s-valuation-in-equilibrium/1547/4)).

recent_posts.title: FROST CLI + BDK CLI Demo
recent_posts.summary:
- FROST enhances Bitcoin with Schnorr signatures and distributed key generation for better security.
- Demonstrations show Bitcoin transactions integration with FROST, including a Trusted Dealer setup and DKG.
- Support and collaboration from organizations and developers aim to advance FROST's application in Bitcoin technology.

recent_posts.title: Delving Simplicity Part Ⅲ: Building Data Types
recent_posts.summary:
- Simplicity is a blockchain language enabling complex computations through basic types and combinators.
- It supports arithmetic operations and cryptographic functions by manipulating bits and logical operations.
- Despite its minimalistic approach, Simplicity offers depth, facilitating secure and efficient blockchain applications.

recent_posts.title: A Game-Theoretic Approach to Bitcoin’s Valuation in Equilibrium
recent_posts.summary:
- The "Hayek" proposes a necessary unit of account for a perfect capital market's function.
- Bitcoin presents a contradiction in academic acceptance as a real-world "Hayek." - Reevaluation of digital currencies like Bitcoin is urged for equitable financial assessment.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Add BIP-0093 (Codex32) as application to BIP-0085
active_posts.summary:
- Ben Westgate proposes integrating BIP-0093 with BIP-0085 to improve wallet backups.
- The integration aims to generate codex32 backups from BIP-32 master keys, enhancing security.
- Community feedback is sought for the proposal, which has begun with a draft PR for Bitcoin Core.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Elliptic Curve Operations for Bitcoin Script
active_posts.summary:
- A proposal aims to enhance Bitcoin scripting with Elliptic Curve operation op codes.
- The initiative seeks to enable dynamic smart contracts on the Bitcoin blockchain.
- It introduces four specific op codes, expanding developers' capabilities for diverse applications.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 29.1 release candidate 2 available
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v29.1rc2 binaries and source code are now available.
- This release candidate invites community testing and feedback via GitHub.
- The update highlights collaborative open-source development efforts in enhancing Bitcoin software.

active_posts.title: CVE-2024-38365 public disclosure (btcd `FindAndDelete` bug)
active_posts.summary:
- Niklas Gögge and Antoine Poinsot discovered a significant flaw in Btcd software versions before 0.24.2.
- Their investigation revealed a deviation from Bitcoin Core's legacy signature verification, risking potential node forking.
- Efforts to fix the flaw included reporting to Olaoluwa Osuntokun, a covert fix, and the awarding of a bug bounty.

active_posts.title: Bitcoin and Quantum Computing
active_posts.summary:
- The collaboration resulted in a report on quantum computing's impact on Bitcoin.
- It outlines potential challenges to Bitcoin's security and proposes quantum-resistant strategies.
- The report promotes proactive community engagement to secure Bitcoin's future against quantum threats.

active_posts.title: Confidential Script: Emulate soft forks using stateless TEEs
active_posts.summary:
- The "confidential-script-lib" emerged at a hackathon, aiming to execute advanced Bitcoin scripts securely.
- Utilizing AWS Nitro Enclave, it ensures code execution is protected from external threats.
- It introduces a novel method combining emulation and signing for minimal trust-dependent script testing.

today_in_history_posts.title: Proposal for a few IANA mime-types related to Bitcoin
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Peter D. Gray proposes three new MIME media types for IANA registration.
- These types facilitate bitcoin transactions, URIs, and PSBT files in binary format.
- Gray invites feedback on the proposal, acknowledging challenges with IANA acceptance.

today_in_history_posts.title: Do we really want users to solve an NP-hard problem when they wish to find a cheap way of paying each	other on the Lightning Network?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rene Pickhardt discussed the Lightning Network's non-linear function issues with ZmnSCPxj.
- ZmnSCPxj proposed a routing method to solve payment problems but noted its practical limitations.
- He suggested adapting Pickhardt-Richter payments for better network performance and lower fees.

today_in_history_posts.title: Hardcoded seeds, DNS seeds and Darknet nodes
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Exploration reveals nuanced reliance of Bitcoin's darknet nodes on hardcoded seed data.
- Viability of hardcoded seeds varies, with IPv4 declining and I2P showing greater longevity.
- Development of a proof-of-concept darknet seeder aims to enhance connectivity for darknet-only nodes.
